notes.title: Precis Writing — method & practice
notes.content: Learn the 4–step précis workflow: (1) read & annotate; (2) find thesis, supports, tone; (3) compress to ~1/3 without examples/quotes; (4) revise for cohesion and neutral voice. Practice on philosophical/literary passages similar to CSS.
keyTakeaways: Keep author's thesis, main supports, and tone; omit examples and rhetoric.
Aim ≈ one-third length; use neutral, impersonal style.
Add a short, precise title that reflects the central claim.

notes.title: Reading Comprehension — strategy kit
notes.content: For CSS passages (history/philosophy/society), use Q-driven reading: skim for structure, read for claims/evidence, then answer by citing the line/idea that justifies your inference. Track tone and key terms.
keyTakeaways: Distinguish main claim vs. supporting examples.
Underline signal words (however, therefore, by contrast).
Answer from text evidence; paraphrase precisely.

notes.title: Grammar — Punctuation essentials
notes.content: CSS repeatedly tests commas, semicolons, colons, dashes, and quotation marks. Master rules for lists, non-restrictive clauses, run-ons, and direct speech punctuation.
keyTakeaways: Comma for non-essential clauses; semicolon to join related independent clauses.
Colon introduces explanations/lists after an independent clause.
Use consistent quotation and punctuation placement.

notes.title: Grammar — Sentence correction & common errors
notes.content: Prepare for subject-verb agreement with correlative pairs, faulty comparison, misplaced/dangling modifiers, redundancy, and tense/pronoun shifts.
keyTakeaways: With 'neither…nor', verb agrees with the nearer subject.
Avoid double negatives and redundant pairs (e.g., 'return back').
Keep tenses consistent; watch modifier placement.

notes.title: Reported/Indirect Speech
notes.content: Master backshift, pronoun/time/place changes, reporting verbs (say/tell/ask/suggest), and question/imperative patterns. CSS often mixes statements, questions, and requests.
keyTakeaways: Backshift tenses after past-time reporting (present → past).
Keep reporting-verb patterns: advise + object + to-infinitive; suggest + -ing/that-clause.
For questions, drop question word order; use if/whether for yes/no.

notes.title: Active vs Passive Voice
notes.content: Know when to prefer active (agent focus) or passive (action/result focus, unknown/irrelevant agent). Convert correctly across tenses and modals.
keyTakeaways: Active: subject does the action; Passive: subject receives it.
Use passive for process focus or unknown agent; avoid clumsy passives.
Mind participle forms and preposition 'by' only when agent matters.

notes.title: Vocabulary — Synonyms, Antonyms & Collocations
notes.content: Build academic vocabulary plus collocations to avoid awkward phrasing. Learn precise contrasts (adverse/averse, venal/venial) and use reputable dictionaries.
keyTakeaways: Use trusted dictionaries + thesaurus for nuance.
Study collocations (make a decision vs. do a decision).
Keep your own word-pair deck with example sentences.

notes.title: Idioms & Phrases — usage in sentences
notes.content: CSS asks for suitable sentences using idioms (e.g., a bolt from the blue). Learn meaning + register + natural context.
keyTakeaways: Don't force literal contexts; pick natural scenarios.
Avoid stacking multiple idioms in one sentence.
Keep tense and point of view consistent.

notes.title: Translation (Urdu → English) — exam tactics
notes.content: Map clauses first; translate sense, not word-for-word. Preserve idioms with natural English equivalents; maintain tense/aspect and politeness.
keyTakeaways: Chunk by clauses; keep connectors (however, therefore).
Prefer idiomatic English equivalents to literal calques.
Revise for flow and coherence after accuracy.

notes.title: Title creation for précis & comprehension answers
notes.content: A strong title captures the passage's central claim in ≤10 words. Use key terms and avoid rhetorical flourishes.
keyTakeaways: Identify thesis → compress to noun phrase or SVO statement.
Prefer concrete over vague (e.g., 'Civil Society Builds Trust' not 'Keys to Progress').
Mirror the author's stance/tone.

notes.title: Past Papers — official & reliable access
notes.content: Use official FPSC listings when available; supplement with clean PDFs for recent years to practice under timed conditions.
keyTakeaways: Practice 1–2 papers/week under 3-hour conditions.
Self-mark with a rubric (precision, cohesion, grammar accuracy).
Maintain an error log by category.

notes.title: Topical Background — Digital Divide & Civil Society (seen in 2020–24 passages)
notes.content: Build background knowledge for analytical questions on globalization, digital inclusion, and civic trust.
keyTakeaways: Know definitions and current stats (offline population, inclusion).
Understand how civil society builds social capital and trust.
Use examples with sources when explaining implications.

notes.title: Topical Background — Voluntary Simplicity / Consumerism
notes.content: Passages might discuss minimalism vs. consumerism. Read a scholarly overview to cite advantages/trade-offs accurately.
keyTakeaways: Voluntary simplicity correlates with well-being in several studies.
Debates: definitional consistency, movement identity, socioeconomic context.

notes.title: Topical Background — Literary/Historical: Manto, Greek Oracles
notes.content: When précis/comprehension passages reference literary figures or ancient practices, a quick primer helps with tone and inference.
keyTakeaways: Know Manto's themes (partition trauma, social hypocrisy).
Understand the Delphic Oracle's role (ambiguity, priestly interpretation).
